article.description: Oklahoma coach Sherri Coale had more than one star player Wednesday night. Oddly, it seemed like Maria Villarroel wasn't just one of them.
article.headline: Villarroel scores 28, has seven rebounds
article.linkText: Villarroel stars in Sooner upset of Colorado
article.story:
NORMAN, Okla. (AP) -- Oklahoma coach Sherri Coale had more than
one star player Wednesday night. Oddly, it seemed like Maria
Villarroel wasn't just one of them.

"It was like there were three Marias on the floor because she
was on the ball, in the passing lane and then she was getting the
rebound," Coale said. "People are wondering how she covered all
that ground."

Villarroel had 28 points, seven rebounds and five assists as the
Sooners (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP) beat No. 13 Colorado 78-58 Wednesday night.

The 5-foot-8 guard hit 11 of 15 shots, including 4 of 7 from
3-point range, and had seven rebounds and five assists.

"Their height didn't stop me at all," Villarroel said. "I was
making plays and I was getting rebounds. I just felt the energy.

"I think that is the best game I have played in my life."

Villarroel had help as all five of Oklahoma's starters finished
in double figures and accounted for all of the team's points.

Dionnah Jackson had 12 points and 11 assists, Caton Hill added
15 points, Erin Higgins scored 12 and Leah Rush 11.

"We changed things all night long and for everyone to be on the
same page is great," Coale said. "That's how you win games and
that's how you beat people that are sometimes more talented than
you."

Tera Bjorklund scored 19 points to lead Colorado (19-5, 8-4 Big
12), which also got 11 points from Kate Fagan and 11 rebounds from
Randie Wirt. The Buffaloes have lost three of four following a
six-game winning streak.

Oklahoma (17-6, 7-5) led 34-30 at halftime, then pulled away
with a 15-6 run to start the second half. Hill scored the final
eight points in the run with two 3-pointers and two free throws.

The Sooners extended their lead to 57-41 before Colorado started
chipping away. The Buffaloes got as close as 64-57 after Bjorklund
hit two free throws to cap an 8-0 spurt.

But the Sooners stormed back, scoring 14 of the game's final 15
points. Oklahoma held Colorado without a basket for the final 4:42.

"I felt like we hung in there and kept fighting," Colorado
coach Ceal Berry said. "We just couldn't get over the hump."

Oklahoma dominated the backboards and kept Colorado from scoring
second-chance baskets. The Sooners had 27 defensive rebounds, and
allowed the Buffaloes just four offensive rebounds.

Overall, the Sooners outrebounded Colorado 35-23.

Both teams had 17 turnovers, but Oklahoma had 23 assists on 28
baskets.
